data.text: Get Rid of the Tick: Permethrin, DEET, etc when Bikepacking?

Let me hear your tick stories/solutions. Permethrin, DEET, essential oils. What do you guys use? I'm terrified of tick borne illnesses. Have you had good or bad luck on your adventures regarding ticks? Just curious.
Get them off you immediately. They longer they are attached to your skin, the greater the risk of disease transmission and skin infection. Check regularly. You can't always feel them.
data.author: Jack Kessler

data.text: I've tried a couple of natural solutions and either they didn't work or they worked for only a couple of minutes, which meant reapplying CONSTANTLY. I use the strongest DEET that I can find, but don't use it anywhere near my rain gear. The stuff works. üëç
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: Permethrin on all your cloths. Do it yourself and put it on thick. Should last you many washings. Still do tick checks every 2 hours when in brush. Trust me you do not want Lyme disease, it destroyed me.
data.author: Jim Dockal

data.text: damn, so you had Lyme disease? Sorry. Have you had any issues since using permethrin?
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: the tick got me before i knew about permethrin. Permethrin is very effective, you will find dead ticks on your cloths, but they wont live long enough to get you. Make sure that you get socks covered with permethrin and all other cloths. DEET is useless.
data.author: Jim Dockal

data.text: This right here is the best advice. DEET is useless. Permethrin and regular checks are the best bet. Make sure you put permethrin on your shoes too, pick up most ticks from the ground.
data.author: Kyle Esposito

data.text: yeah I plan to get long socks and spray them. Maybe get some sun leggings or whatever and spray those too. Lol anything to avoid those hellish creatures.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I recommend long pants. Ticks don't jump so it's typically from vegetation on your legs.
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: Not sure where you reside or ride but in N.A. there are pants, shirts and hats that kill the insects. Made for Canadian Tire and Mark's. This one hitched a ride for more than a week before discovered and removed.
data.author: Bill Dove

data.text: so gross lol. My wife had a truck in her shoulder a few years ago that I removed. Gross.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: good question
data.author: Maury Wood

data.text: it's all about awareness. before entering your tent, once inside it, isolating outdoor clothing from sleeping clothing, cellphone camera checks. i find my solar leggings a real saving grace, since they are white, and it's easy to spot ticks making their way up. having a bright coloured tent floor is helpful too. walking through tall grass to take a leak? check legs before getting on your bike, and again in five minutes in case they were on your shoes. the best advice: come bike in northern Canada! we just don't have them, at all. they are sneaking up in southern bc though
data.author: Brent Joly

data.text: If you do find an engorged deer tick that may have been on there for 24 hours or more, be prepared to head into town and find some doxycycline. A 200 mg prophylactic dose will pretty much guarantee you don't get lyme. If possible take pictures of the tick before and after removing.
data.author: J.c. Mcguirk

data.text: If you can get Permethrin in your country, it‚Äôs the way to go. You soak all the clothes you intend to tour in. It stays in your clothes for about 10 washings. Also, use DEET on your skin where you might come in contact with tall grasses or vegetation. Ticks hang out on the tips of grasses or leaves and wait for you walk by and brush up against them. I would try wash the DEET off of your hands after applying so you don‚Äôt get it on your grips. That stuff will break down some plastics and synthetic fibers in clothing‚Ä¶like spandex in bike clothes.
data.author: James Logan

data.text: If you ever come to Scotland be really careful - I got lymes last year and am only just feeling like I'm recovering now üòì it's rife here
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: that sucks. I grew up in the Northeastern part of the USA. I think we have the highest concentration of Lyme disease and ticks. Brutal here.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: yeah its a huge problem here now too üò¨
data.author: Rosie Baxendine

data.text: Never had a problem
data.author: Daniel Murphy

data.text: I just rub myself down in the tick spray but I also don't go in tall grass and bushes. Long socks/pants off the bike. I'm also not out in the wild for more than 3 days so they don't have a lot of time to get me lol.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: glad to hear you haven't had much of a problem.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Permethrin on clothing (plus shoes, socks, hat, etc.) and some gear. I don't treat my tent or sleeping bag. If needed I also use Picaridin on my skin, but that's rare with the Permethrin treated clothing.
data.author: Patty Cartwright

data.text: Permethrin on your gear and Picaridin on your skin.
data.author: Brian Stewart

data.text: Permithrin for my clothes. Picardin for my skin. Deet for those fearless, bloodsucking, winged lil' mofos.
data.author: Aaron Crawford

data.text: During tick season, I tuck my pants into my socks, wear a long sleeved sun shirt with the collar turned up & wear a hat when not wearing my bike helmet. I also do a tick check before or just after getting into my tent. Last time I checked, Permethrin was not sold in Canada, unless you bought the one meant for horses, though we‚Äôve had ticks that spread Lyme disease in southern BC for many years.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: I've gotten very sick from ticks. I now avoid riding overgrown trails or camping in grass. I do carry Deet wipes (packs very easy) if the need arises & and do a quick tick check if brush was unavoidable. Personally I don't apply bug repellent routinely.
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: so I've been buying all this gear, bought a pinion bike, super excited to go on adventures and then ticks came to mind. Now I'm contemplating selling everything. I have such a fear of tick borne illnesses. Every time I go into the woods I come back and check 1000 times over and I still feel like there's something crawling on me. I'm also in the northeast ATM where there are tons of ticks and lots of Lyme disease. I'm sorry to hear you got sick from ticks. One of my nightmares.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Its not a huge risk in my eye. I very rarely get a tick & that's usually when I'm not being careful (like laying in grass in shorts/t-shirt). As long as you extract it carefully within 24 hrs the chance of it spreading a disease IF it was carrying one is minimal. I carry a small tick removal tool but have never had to use it. Being prepared with DEET wipes, removal tool & by avoiding grassy fields or overgrown trails is of great comfort
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: Use duct tape or wide masking tape, sticky side out, around clothes below knees, to catch ticks crawling up.
data.author: Dane Harrel
